text:
I find it interesting that people constantly compare Python and Julia on HN from the perspective of “there can only be one” — it’s like, _you can use Python from Julia._

I can basically predict what the distribution of comments is going to be before even opening the threads now. There’s some Python fan people complaining about young ecosystem issues in Julia, some other people complaining about time to plot. Some other people pearl clutching TIOBE as if that’s relevant _at all_ to composable, scientific software engineering.

The whole thing baffles me. It’s like people momentarily forget what an API is. Or that *gasp* you can and should use multiple languages together when necessary.

text:
We have recently started a new project in Python and Julia, with the idea that the backend calculations needs to be fast and that the interface and data-reading stuff can be as slow as whatever. Our team is extremely confident in Python, and I am the only Julia dev. We managed to split the roles into Python for building the basic structure of the project, and me as the lone Julia dev, for building the back-end calculation engine. The other team members was blown away by the ease at which you can integrate the Python object via. PyCall.

But, it's not the perfect working environment. It really does help to have everything under one language. But it is still so much better trying to bring everyone up to scratch on Julia, or trying to build computing models under Python.

text: One thing that is also quite nice with our implementation is that our entry-point is Julia, and not Python. That means as the project matures and some of the code gets re-written, Julia will most likely absorb the Python code until nothing snakey is left. Or until only specific Python library calls are used. The other nice thing is that the Julia's semantics is a superset of Python's (or at least that is how it seems). I.e. you can have Python objects in Julia, but you cannot have multiple dispatch in Python. So the only way to grow forward is to grow the Julia side.

text: One downside it that Julia is about 3 times the size of Python. Without any library dependencies, a Python program that is shipped with the Python binaries is about 20mb (compressed). With numpy and pandas, it reaches about 40mb. With matplotlib added to the mix it reaches about 60mb. Julia starts at 60mb, I think it easily reaches 120mb. If you combine the two, you have a binary weight of roughly 200mb.
